Monitoring Multiple Clusters with the &hawk;2 Dashboard
The cluster information displayed in the Dashboard is stored on the server side and synchronized between the cluster nodes (if passwordless SSH access between the cluster nodes has been configured). For details, see the &haguide; for &productname;, available from . Refer to chapter Running Cluster Reports Without &rootuser; Access, section Configuring a Passwordless SSH Account. However, the machine you are running &hawk;2 on does not even need to be part of any cluster for that purpose—it can be a separate, unrelated system.
Monitoring Multiple Clusters with &hawk;2
Prerequisites
All clusters to be monitored from &hawk;'s Dashboard must be running &productname; &productnumber;. It is not possible to monitor clusters that are running earlier versions of &productname;.
If you did not replace the self-signed certificate for &hawk;2 on every cluster node with your own certificate (or a certificate signed by an official Certificate Authority), log in to &hawk;2 on every node in every cluster at least once. Verify the certificate (or add an exception in the browser to bypass the warning).
Start the &hawk; Web service on a machine you want to use for monitoring multiple clusters.
Start a Web browser and as URL enter the IP address or host name of the machine that runs &hawk;2: https://IPaddress:7630/
Log in to the &hawk;2 Web interface.
From the left navigation bar, select Dashboard.
To add dashboards for multiple clusters, click Add Cluster.
Enter a custom Cluster name with which to identify the cluster in the Dashboard.
Enter the Hostname of a node in the cluster.
To specify further options like the update interval for &hawk;2, the port to connect to or if to use HTTPS (default), click Advanced and enter the details.
Confirm your changes with Add.
To add more clusters to the dashboard, click Add Cluster again and enter the details for the next cluster.
&hawk;2—Dashboard
To remove a cluster from the dashboard, click the x icon next to the cluster's name.
To view details about a cluster, enter a password and click Connect.
&hawk;2 will show you a summary with the status of the respective nodes, resources, and tickets.
Clicking a cluster name will take you to the Status view for that cluster, from where you can administer it as usual.
Any status changes for nodes or resources are reflected almost immediately within the Dashboard.
Managing Tickets with &hawk;2
Tickets are visible in &hawk;2 if they have been granted or revoked at least once or if they are referenced in a ticket dependency.
&hawk;2 displays the following ticket states:
Granted: Tickets that are granted to the current site.
Revoked: Tickets that have been revoked. Additionally, &hawk;2 also displays tickets as revoked if they are referenced in a ticket dependency, but have not been granted to any site yet.
Granting Tickets to Current Site
Though you can view tickets for all sites with &hawk;2, any grant operations triggered by &hawk;2 only apply to the current site (that you are currently connected to with &hawk;2). To grant a ticket to another site of your &geo; cluster, start &hawk;2 on one of the cluster nodes belonging to the respective site.
You can only grant tickets that are not already given to any site.
Viewing, Granting and Revoking Tickets with &hawk;2
Start a Web browser and log in to &hawk;2.
In the left navigation bar, select Status.
Along with information about cluster nodes and resources, &hawk;2 also displays a Tickets category. It lists the ticket status, the ID of the constraint that references the ticket, and the ticket name. The Ticket category also contains two columns for managing the tickets.
To show details for a certain ticket, click the Details icon next to the ticket. A window shows if the ticket has been already granted, which Loss Policy has been set (for the case that a ticket gets revoked from a site), and which resources depend on the ticket.
&hawk;2—Ticket Details
To revoke a granted ticket from the current site or to grant a ticket to the current site, click the switch in the Granted column next to the ticket. On click, it shows the available action. Confirm your choice when &hawk;2 prompts for a confirmation.
If the ticket cannot be granted or revoked for any reason, &hawk;2 shows an error message. If the ticket has been successfully granted or revoked, &hawk;2 will update the ticket Status.
